message: I find it hard to test the web UI. The functionality is not too bad since I can cross check, the UI is harder because often the test changes with the changed code.
User selenium2 with the new webdriver stuff, and the pageobjects pattern: http://pragprog.com/magazines/2010-08/page-objects-in-python
Hey y'all, convore's got this neat "star" feature, so there's not really a need for +1s... ;-)
I'll give selenium2 a go. I could use any help at this point. It is very tedious to check say 40 screens every time a change is made. Especially when changing the model causes changes automatically.

@jkelkar yeah, we have thousands of pages in our product that our QA department is just now starting to test with Selenium.  I bet they wish they would have started writing Selenium tests a long time ago!
of course, there's also the occasional program that will save several hours a day..
but most of them are just 5 seconds here and there

I don't like it when I have to do this kind of thing manually. The question foremost in my mind is "what have I missed?". And the other is "is it still fixed?". With Selemium2 I am looking to implement "click to test", my dream anyway.
@jkelkar and this is why I program. I will spend hours, days, weeks, and months trying to perfect something that will save me 5 seconds an hour.  I love it.
Selenium2 + Nose == Fully automated GUI regression tool. Works like a charm. Have developers define the core page objects and assertions.

A decent amount of the code I write seems to be long running or services and a small improvement can matter a lot. I started on a machine with 1KB RAM and have not forgotten it. To me efficiency matters.

@jessenoller I will start on this combo come Monday. Today I have an all day NYLT preparation session - I am on staff with National Youth Leadership Training in Atlanta Area, a Boy Scouting program. I also run NYLT IT at http://aacnylt.org That is in php. Are there any starter projects or examples out there? I tend to learn a lot faster from people directly or examples rather than reading docs only. Thanks.
@codekoala I feel the same. For me #1 is accuracy and a close #2 is performance.

@jkelkar I can't share what I've worked on, but I can link to: http://pragprog.com/magazines/2010-08/page-objects-in-python and https://gist.github.com/830011 and http://www.slideshare.net/hugs/selenium-2-webinar-the-next-generation-of-web-and-mobile-application-testing
